title: Ezekiel Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 16.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:3, what was Jerusalem's father?
questions.correctAnswer: An Amorite
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:3 states, 'thy father was an Amorite,' indicating Jerusalem's father was an Amorite.

questions.question: What did God do when He saw Jerusalem polluted in her blood according to Ezekiel 16:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Said Live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:6 records God saying to Jerusalem in her blood, 'Live; yea, I said unto thee when thou wast in thy blood, Live.'

questions.question: What did God spread over Jerusalem to cover her nakedness in Ezekiel 16:8?
questions.correctAnswer: His skirt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:8 says God 'spread my skirt over thee, and covered thy nakedness.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:12, what was placed on Jerusalem's forehead?
questions.correctAnswer: A jewel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:12 states, 'And I put a jewel on thy forehead.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 16:15 says Jerusalem trusted in her own beauty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:15 states, 'But thou didst trust in thine own beauty.'

questions.question: What did Jerusalem take to decorate her high places, according to Ezekiel 16:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Garments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:16 states, 'And of thy garments thou didst take, and deckedst thy high places with divers colours.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:20, what did Jerusalem sacrifice to idols?
questions.correctAnswer: Sons and daughters
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:20 says, 'Moreover thou hast taken thy sons and thy daughters... and these hast thou sacrificed unto them to be devoured.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 16:25 says Jerusalem made her beauty to be abhorred.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:25 states, 'and hast made thy beauty to be abhorred.'

questions.question: With which neighbors did Jerusalem commit fornication according to Ezekiel 16:26?
questions.correctAnswer: Egyptians
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:26 states, 'Thou hast also committed fornication with the Egyptians thy neighbours.'

questions.question: Who are called Jerusalem's elder and younger sisters in Ezekiel 16:46?
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria and Sodom
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:46 identifies Jerusalem's elder sister as Samaria and her younger sister as Sodom.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 16:48 says Sodom and her daughters committed more abominations than Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:48 states that Sodom did not do as Jerusalem did; Jerusalem was corrupted more than they.

questions.question: What will God establish with Jerusalem according to Ezekiel 16:60?
questions.correctAnswer: An everlasting covenant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:60 says, 'I will establish unto thee an everlasting covenant.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I clothed thee also with broidered work, and shod thee with ________.' (Ezekiel 16:10)
questions.correctAnswer: badgers' skin
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:10 says, 'I clothed thee also with broidered work, and shod thee with badgers' skin.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And I put a jewel on thy forehead, and earrings in thine ears, and a beautiful ______ upon thine head.' (Ezekiel 16:12)
questions.correctAnswer: crown
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:12 states, 'and a beautiful crown upon thine head.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:37, what will God do with all Jerusalem's lovers?
options: Gather them round about against her
questions.correctAnswer: Gather them round about against her
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:37 says God will gather all her lovers against her to expose her nakedness.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of abandonment and worthlessness. Based on Ezekiel 16:5-7, what biblical truth would you share about God's care and restoration?
options: God did not abandon Jerusalem but caused her to live and flourish despite her beginnings.
God ignores those who are abandoned and focuses only on the righteous.
Human effort alone restores worth and status in God's eyes.
Only perfect obedience guarantees God's favor and restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: God did not abandon Jerusalem but caused her to live and flourish despite her beginnings.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:5-7 shows that though Jerusalem was abandoned and rejected at birth, God passed by, saw her plight, and said 'Live', causing her to multiply and prosper. This teaches us God’s compassion and power to restore (verses 5, 6, 7).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 16:8-14 illustrate the importance of God's covenant and blessings in our spiritual growth?
options: God’s covenant brings cleansing, anointing, and adornment symbolizing spiritual blessing.
God’s blessings are only external and not related to spiritual life.
God’s covenant is conditional only on external rituals.
Spiritual growth depends purely on human effort without God’s involvement.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant brings cleansing, anointing, and adornment symbolizing spiritual blessing.
questions.explanation: Verses 8-14 describe how God covered Jerusalem’s nakedness, washed her, anointed her, clothed her, and adorned her with ornaments, symbolizing covenantal blessing and spiritual growth. This shows the significance of God's covenant and grace in transforming us (Ezekiel 16:8-14).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:15-17, what warning can be drawn about trusting in one’s own beauty or accomplishments instead of God?
options: Trusting in self leads to spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry.
Beauty and accomplishments are the highest spiritual goals.
Ignoring God leads to automatic blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in self leads to spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-17 warn that Jerusalem trusted in her own beauty and played the harlot, making idols from God's gifts. This illustrates the danger of relying on self rather than God, which leads to unfaithfulness and sin (Ezekiel 16:15-17).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their faith for worldly gain. Based on Ezekiel 16:18-22, what biblical principle would you emphasize about true devotion to God?
options: True devotion requires faithfulness and rejecting idolatry, even at personal cost.
Compromise is acceptable if it leads to prosperity.
Using God’s blessings for idols is a sign of spiritual maturity.
questions.correctAnswer: True devotion requires faithfulness and rejecting idolatry, even at personal cost.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:18-22 condemns setting God's gifts before idols and sacrificing children, showing unfaithfulness. The passage teaches that genuine devotion means rejecting idolatry and remaining faithful regardless of costs (Ezekiel 16:18-22).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 16:23-26 warn believers about the consequences of building spiritual high places and unfaithfulness?
options: Unfaithfulness leads to spiritual ruin and provokes God’s anger.
Building high places guarantees God’s blessing.
Spiritual high places are a symbol of faithfulness.
God ignores unfaithfulness if worship continues.
questions.correctAnswer: Unfaithfulness leads to spiritual ruin and provokes God’s anger.
questions.explanation: These verses describe Jerusalem building high places and multiplying whoredoms, provoking God’s anger and leading to judgment. This warns believers that unfaithfulness and idolatry result in serious consequences (Ezekiel 16:23-26).

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 16:27-29, what lesson about contentment and the dangers of spiritual insatiability can be learned?
options: Insatiable desire leads to spiritual destruction and judgment.
More spiritual partners bring greater satisfaction.
Spiritual hunger is always good and should be increased.
God rewards those who increase their idols.
questions.correctAnswer: Insatiable desire leads to spiritual destruction and judgment.
questions.explanation: Verses 27-29 reveal Jerusalem’s insatiable whoredoms with neighbors, provoking God’s anger and leading to diminished provision and captivity. This teaches that unchecked spiritual desire outside God leads to ruin (Ezekiel 16:27-29).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 16:30-34 explains that Jerusalem’s unfaithfulness was like that of a harlot who accepts payment for her services.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: These verses describe Jerusalem as unlike a harlot who scorns hire; instead, she pays her lovers to come to her, showing deeper corruption (Ezekiel 16:30-34).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 16:35-43 teach us about God's judgment on unfaithfulness and the hope for repentance?
options: God will judge sin but also cease anger when repentance happens.
Judgment is final with no hope for restoration.
Repentance is unnecessary for God’s mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge sin but also cease anger when repentance happens.
questions.explanation: Verses 35-43 describe God’s judgment on Jerusalem’s sins but also promise that His fury will rest and jealousy depart when He is pacified, showing hope for repentance and restoration (Ezekiel 16:35-43).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:44-52, what practical lesson about humility and self-examination can believers learn from Jerusalem's comparison to her sisters Samaria and Sodom?
options: Believers should humbly recognize their own sins rather than judge others.
Being worse than others justifies pride.
Judging others without self-examination is encouraged.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should humbly recognize their own sins rather than judge others.
questions.explanation: Jerusalem judged her sisters but was more corrupt herself. God calls her to bear shame and be confounded, teaching believers to practice humility and self-examination instead of judging others (Ezekiel 16:44-52).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 16:53-55 teaches that when the captives of Sodom and Samaria return to their former estate, ________ will also return to their former estate.
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem and her daughters
questions.explanation: Verses 53-55 state that when Sodom and Samaria and their daughters return to their former estate, Jerusalem and her daughters will also return to their former estate, showing restoration for all (Ezekiel 16:53-55).

questions.question: A believer feels prideful about their spiritual status. According to Ezekiel 16:56-58, what warning should they heed?
options: Pride before the discovery of sin leads to reproach and despising God’s covenant.
Pride is a sign of spiritual maturity.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride before the discovery of sin leads to reproach and despising God’s covenant.
questions.explanation: Verses 56-58 warn that Jerusalem was proud before her wickedness was revealed and despised the covenant, leading to judgment. This teaches that pride leads to downfall (Ezekiel 16:56-58).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 16:59-63 offer hope to believers who have broken their covenant with God?
options: God remembers His covenant and will establish an everlasting covenant despite past failures.
Once broken, God’s covenant is void forever.
No restoration is possible after covenant-breaking.
God ignores repentance and continues to punish.
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers His covenant and will establish an everlasting covenant despite past failures.
questions.explanation: Verses 59-63 declare that although the covenant was broken, God will remember His covenant from youth and establish an everlasting covenant, offering hope for restoration (Ezekiel 16:59-63).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 16 teaches that forgiveness from God leads to shame and silence about past sin, so believers should openly confess and not be ashamed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 63 says that remembering God’s pacification causes shame and silence about past sin, implying that confession and humility are integral to forgiveness (Ezekiel 16:63).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:20-22, what is a serious consequence of spiritual unfaithfulness that believers must avoid?
options: Sacrificing children to idols is condemned as an abomination.
Spiritual unfaithfulness has no real consequences.
God accepts sacrifices regardless of their nature.
Unfaithfulness is only a private matter.
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificing children to idols is condemned as an abomination.
questions.explanation: These verses condemn Jerusalem for sacrificing her children to idols, highlighting the seriousness of unfaithfulness and idolatry, and warning believers to avoid such abominations (Ezekiel 16:20-22).

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling tempted to put trust in their own achievements. Based on Ezekiel 16:14-15, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trusting in God's gifts rather than one’s own beauty leads to true faithfulness.
God’s gifts are irrelevant to spiritual trust.
Self-reliance is the foundation of godliness.
Achievements guarantee God’s favor without faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in God's gifts rather than one’s own beauty leads to true faithfulness.
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 show Jerusalem’s renown came from God’s comeliness, but she trusted in her own beauty and played the harlot. This teaches believers to rely on God's grace rather than self (Ezekiel 16:14-15).

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 16.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 16, Jerusalem's origins are described symbolically. According to Ezekiel 16:3, what is Jerusalem's parentage?
options: Father was an Amorite and mother a Hittite
Father was an Egyptian and mother a Canaanite
Father was a Philistine and mother a Moabite
Father was a Babylonian and mother an Assyrian
questions.correctAnswer: Father was an Amorite and mother a Hittite
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:3 explicitly states Jerusalem's father was an Amorite and her mother a Hittite, indicating her origins in the Canaanite nations.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used throughout Ezekiel 16 to describe Jerusalem's relationship with God?
questions.correctAnswer: Allegory of marriage and adultery
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16 uses the allegory of Jerusalem as a wife who commits adultery and harlotry to symbolize spiritual unfaithfulness (Ezekiel 16:32).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16, how did God initially care for Jerusalem when she was 'cast out in the open field'?
options: God passed by, saw her polluted, and said 'Live'
questions.correctAnswer: God passed by, saw her polluted, and said 'Live'
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:6 describes God passing by Jerusalem when she was polluted in her own blood and commanding her to live, showing divine compassion.

questions.question: What cultural practice is alluded to in Ezekiel 16:4 regarding Jerusalem's birth?
options: Her navel was not cut and she was not washed or swaddled
She was anointed with olive oil at birth
She was dedicated at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Her navel was not cut and she was not washed or swaddled
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:4 describes the newborn Jerusalem as untreated in typical ancient Near Eastern customs, emphasizing her abandoned state.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 16:8, what covenantal action does God take with Jerusalem?
options: Spreading His skirt over her and entering into a covenant
Sending an army to defend her
questions.correctAnswer: Spreading His skirt over her and entering into a covenant
questions.explanation: The phrase 'spread my skirt over thee' in Ezekiel 16:8 is a Hebrew idiom for marriage and covenant commitment.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly parallels the theme of spiritual adultery found in Ezekiel 16?
options: Revelation 17 describing the harlot on the beast
questions.correctAnswer: Revelation 17 describing the harlot on the beast
questions.explanation: Revelation 17 uses similar imagery of a harlot to symbolize unfaithful Jerusalem and apostate religious systems, echoing Ezekiel 16’s theme.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 16:20-21 accuse Jerusalem of doing that was particularly abhorrent in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Sacrificing her sons and daughters to idols
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificing her sons and daughters to idols
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:20-21 condemns the sacrifice of children to idols, likely referring to practices like Molech worship, which was abominable to Israel’s God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 16:26-29, Jerusalem’s unfaithfulness included alliances and fornication with foreign nations such as the Egyptians, Assyrians, and Chaldeans.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:26-29 explicitly mentions Jerusalem’s fornication with neighbors including Egyptians, Assyrians, and Chaldeans as symbolic of political and spiritual unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare in Ezekiel 16:39-40 for Jerusalem’s spiritual adultery?
options: She will be stripped, stoned, and her houses burned
She will be exalted above all nations
She will be forgotten by all nations
questions.correctAnswer: She will be stripped, stoned, and her houses burned
questions.explanation: The judgment described in Ezekiel 16:39-40 is graphic and shows the severity of punishment for spiritual adultery, including public disgrace and destruction.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 16:44 use proverb and typology to describe Jerusalem’s sinfulness?
options: As the daughter resembling her mother in abominations
As a lion and a lamb
As a desert and a garden
As a judge and a victim
questions.correctAnswer: As the daughter resembling her mother in abominations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:44 uses the proverb 'As is the mother, so is her daughter' to typify generational sin and unfaithfulness passed from the mother (Jerusalem’s origins) to the daughter (Jerusalem).

questions.question: Which sister cities are mentioned in Ezekiel 16:46 as comparisons to Jerusalem's sinfulness?
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria and Sodom
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:46 refers to Samaria and Sodom as elder and younger sisters illustrating different types of sin, yet Jerusalem is said to be more corrupt.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16:49-50, what was the specific sin of Sodom that led to its destruction?
options: Pride, fullness of bread, idleness, and not helping the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Pride, fullness of bread, idleness, and not helping the poor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:49-50 lists social injustice and pride as Sodom’s sins, emphasizing neglect of the needy as a key factor in divine judgment.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 16:60-62 promise despite Jerusalem’s unfaithfulness?
options: An everlasting covenant will be established
questions.correctAnswer: An everlasting covenant will be established
questions.explanation: Despite Jerusalem’s sins, Ezekiel 16:60-62 contains a promise of God remembering His covenant and establishing an everlasting covenant.

questions.question: How does the imagery of clothing and adornment function in Ezekiel 16:9-14?
options: It symbolizes God's blessing and Jerusalem's exalted status
It illustrates the wealth of surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's blessing and Jerusalem's exalted status
questions.explanation: The detailed description of washing, anointing, and adorning with fine clothes and jewels in Ezekiel 16:9-14 symbolizes God’s favor and Jerusalem’s initial beauty and prosperity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 16, Jerusalem’s unfaithfulness was unique and even exceeded the sins of Samaria and Sodom.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:47-52 explicitly states Jerusalem was more corrupt and committed more abominations than her sisters Samaria and Sodom.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 16, what is the origin of Jerusalem as described in the chapter?
options: Her birth and nativity are of the land of Canaan; her father was an Amorite and her mother a Hittite
She was created directly by God without human parents
She was founded by the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Her birth and nativity are of the land of Canaan; her father was an Amorite and her mother a Hittite
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:3 explicitly states Jerusalem’s origins as being of the land of Canaan, with an Amorite father and Hittite mother. This highlights human and sinful origins, consistent with humanity's fall as in Genesis 3 and Israel's human ancestry in Romans 9:4-5.

questions.question: What act of God toward Jerusalem is described as 'spreading his skirt over her' and entering into a covenant?
options: God's act of betrothal and covenant making with Jerusalem
God's act of judgment and punishment
questions.correctAnswer: God's act of betrothal and covenant making with Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:8 uses the metaphor of spreading a skirt to illustrate God’s covenantal commitment and betrothal to Jerusalem, similar to the marriage covenant imagery in Hosea 2:19-20 and Isaiah 54:5, reflecting God's covenant faithfulness (2 Corinthians 11:2).

questions.question: How did God describe Jerusalem’s condition at birth in Ezekiel 16?
options: Her navel was not cut, not washed, salted, nor swaddled; she was cast out to the open field
She was born fully prepared and cared for by many
She was bathed in the Jordan River immediately after birth
She was honored and celebrated by her people
questions.correctAnswer: Her navel was not cut, not washed, salted, nor swaddled; she was cast out to the open field
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:4-5 describes Jerusalem’s helpless and forsaken state at birth, symbolizing spiritual abandonment and sinfulness, paralleling the human condition apart from grace (Psalm 51:5; Romans 3:23; Isaiah 1:6).

questions.question: What was God's response when He saw Jerusalem in her polluted state at birth?
options: God said to her, 'Live'; He chose to give life and restoration
God immediately judged and rejected her
God handed her over to enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God said to her, 'Live'; He chose to give life and restoration
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:6 reveals God's grace in choosing life over death for Jerusalem despite her polluted state, reflecting the doctrine of grace (Ephesians 2:4-5; John 10:10; Ezekiel 37:5).

questions.question: What blessings and adornments did God bestow upon Jerusalem after her restoration?
options: Clothing of embroidered work, fine linen, silk, jewels, bracelets, a crown, and provision of fine flour, honey, and oil
questions.correctAnswer: Clothing of embroidered work, fine linen, silk, jewels, bracelets, a crown, and provision of fine flour, honey, and oil
questions.explanation: Verses 10-13 describe God's rich blessings and adornments symbolizing covenantal grace and divine favor, paralleling the imagery of the bride in Isaiah 61:10 and the new creation garments in Revelation 19:8.

questions.question: What sin did Jerusalem commit after being richly blessed by God according to Ezekiel 16?
options: She played the harlot, trusted in her own beauty, and committed idolatry
She built more altars to the LORD
She repented and turned back to God
questions.correctAnswer: She played the harlot, trusted in her own beauty, and committed idolatry
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:15-17 describes Jerusalem’s unfaithfulness as spiritual adultery and idolatry, a common biblical metaphor for covenant unfaithfulness (Jeremiah 3:6-8; Hosea 1-3; James 4:4).

questions.question: Jerusalem is accused of sacrificing her children to idols. What does this signify in biblical theology?
options: Extreme apostasy and rejection of God's covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Extreme apostasy and rejection of God's covenant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:20-21 condemns child sacrifice, symbolizing profound rebellion against God, consistent with biblical denunciations of such practices (Leviticus 18:21; Deuteronomy 12:31; Jeremiah 7:31).

questions.question: How does God describe Jerusalem's heart in light of her persistent sinning?
options: Weak and imperious, continuing in lewdness
questions.correctAnswer: Weak and imperious, continuing in lewdness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:30 characterizes Jerusalem’s heart as weak and rebellious, illustrating human depravity and the hardness of heart in sin (Romans 8:7; Jeremiah 17:9; Hebrews 3:12).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 16, what judgment does God declare against Jerusalem for her sins?
options: She will be judged as a woman who breaks wedlock, suffering destruction, stoning, and burning
She will receive immediate forgiveness without judgment
She will be exalted above her sisters
questions.correctAnswer: She will be judged as a woman who breaks wedlock, suffering destruction, stoning, and burning
questions.explanation: Verses 38-41 describe the severe judgment due to Jerusalem’s covenant unfaithfulness, consistent with Old Testament judgments for idolatry and apostasy (Deuteronomy 13:6-11; Joshua 7:25; Revelation 2:22).

questions.question: Which two cities are named as Jerusalem’s sisters, and how does Jerusalem compare to them in sinfulness?
options: Samaria and Sodom; Jerusalem is more corrupt than both
Babylon and Nineveh; Jerusalem is less sinful
Jericho and Hebron; Jerusalem is equally sinful
Tyre and Sidon; Jerusalem is innocent
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria and Sodom; Jerusalem is more corrupt than both
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:46-47 states Samaria and Sodom as Jerusalem’s sisters, with Jerusalem being more corrupt, highlighting the severity of her covenant unfaithfulness (Jeremiah 23:14; Isaiah 1:4; Matthew 11:23).

questions.question: What specific sins of Sodom are highlighted in Ezekiel 16 as a contrast to Jerusalem’s sins?
options: Pride, fullness of bread, and neglect of the poor and needy
questions.correctAnswer: Pride, fullness of bread, and neglect of the poor and needy
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:49 describes Sodom’s sins as pride and social injustice, aligning with Genesis 19:4-13 and New Testament teachings condemning pride and neglect of the needy (James 4:6; Luke 16:19-31).

questions.question: What does God promise regarding His covenant with Jerusalem despite her rebellion?
options: God will establish an everlasting covenant and remember His covenant from her youth
God will reject Jerusalem forever with no covenant
God will transfer the covenant to another nation
God will remain silent and inactive
questions.correctAnswer: God will establish an everlasting covenant and remember His covenant from her youth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:60-62 promises God's faithfulness to His covenant despite Israel’s sins, consistent with His unchanging nature (Hebrews 13:8; Jeremiah 31:31-34; Romans 11:29).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 16 use the imagery of a wife committing adultery to describe Jerusalem's sin?
options: Jerusalem is like a wife who takes strangers instead of her husband, symbolizing spiritual adultery against God
Jerusalem is a faithful wife who never strays
Jerusalem is a virgin untouched by sin
Jerusalem is a mother nurturing her children in righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem is like a wife who takes strangers instead of her husband, symbolizing spiritual adultery against God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:32-33 employs marital infidelity as a metaphor for Israel’s idolatry, a biblical theme seen in Hosea 1-3 and Jeremiah 3:8-9, illustrating covenant violation and God's jealousy (Exodus 20:5).

questions.question: What is the significance of God covering Jerusalem’s nakedness and anointing her with oil in Ezekiel 16?
options: It symbolizes cleansing, restoration, and divine favor
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes cleansing, restoration, and divine favor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:9 portrays God's act of washing and anointing as cleansing from sin and bestowing favor, paralleling the ritual of consecration (Psalm 23:5; Isaiah 61:3; 1 John 1:7).

questions.question: What role does the metaphor of clothing and adornments play in Ezekiel 16's teaching about Jerusalem’s relationship with God?
options: They signify God’s covenantal grace, beauty, and chosen status before her fall
They represent her material wealth alone
They show her political power without spiritual meaning
They indicate her shame and nakedness
questions.correctAnswer: They signify God’s covenantal grace, beauty, and chosen status before her fall
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 16:10-14 uses rich clothing and jewels to symbolize God's gracious blessings and the beauty of the covenant relationship, echoing themes in Isaiah 61:10 and Revelation 19:7-8 about the bride adorned for her husband.
